title_sort: manvill wintersteen to walt whitman, 8 august 1875
title: Manvill Wintersteen to Walt Whitman, 8 August 1875
text: Hampden, Ohio,August 8, 1875Kind sur[sir] Uncl[Uncle]I recived[received] your welcom[welcome] and expecd[expected] letter lost was glad to here[hear] from you I neglect wrighting[writing] for I am not much on a right but I must wright[write] to you Moather[Mother] ses[says] I aughtought to right[write] to one that was a friend in time of need I am glad to know that you are livingI should like to see you very much if I could I would but traviling[traveling] cost money and I did not get much from where I am I suppose their[there] is not much call for help in Campdin[Camden]I get 4 dollers[dollars] per month pencion[pension] but every little helps in hard times very plesent[pleasant] weather and crops look well here since the rain we had last weak[week] I am working by the month since I came home from York StStateI can come home very Sunday and as I looked at your pictur[picture] I sed[said] I must wright[write] eny how[anyhow] if ever so poor a letter but you will excuse from a friend though many miles away this world is ful[full] of trouble and we and we all have our share sum[some] is blest[blessed] with health and wealth while others...want but I am glad to get along and be most wellI can allways[always] find work wright[write] againMy love to you and good wishes, Yours truly Manvill Wintersteen to Walt Whitman, 8 August 1875
